body:
@tenderlove that seems reasonable, although not as reliable. The idea
would be as-is on Windows and OSX, gem 'therubyracer' on everything
else?

This could make a mistake -- someone on Win or OSX might not actually
have a JS runtime that execjs can find for some odd reason. But that's
neccesarily so bad a 'failure mode'.

Worse, someone on linux might have node.js installed and not need
therubyracer, but the generator will add it to gemfile anyway, making
them wait through the too-lengthy bundle install and compilation for
it before they even have the chance to go and remove it from their
Gemfile (if they're smart enough to not need it).  Which is def going
to annoy some 'power users'.

Using execjs seems the RIGHT way to do it, but the cost is a
dependency. Trade offs either way. Ultimately your call (or other
rails core team) I think, what do you think?

On Thu, Jan 12, 2012 at 12:41 PM, Aaron Patterson
<reply@reply.github.com>
wrote:
> Could we just do platform detection and emit "good defaults" depending on the platform?  That would let us avoid runtime detection.
